MERCURY.name: mercury
MERCURY.first:
^800The smallest planet in our solar system and^100
nearest to the Sun, Mercury is only slightly ^100
larger than Earth's Moon.
MERCURY.introduction:
surface temperatures :800°F(430°C) ~ -290°F(-180°C)^100
the fastest planet, zipping around the Sun every ^100
88 Earth days.
MERCURY.namesake: named for the swiftest of the ancient Roman gods.
MERCURY.potential:
Mercury's environment is not conducive to life ^100
as we know it. The temperatures and solar radiation that^100
characterize this planet are most likely too extreme for^100
organisms to adapt to.
MERCURY.structure:
Mercury is the second densest planet, after Earth.^100
It has a large metallic core with a radius of about 1,289 miles^100
(2,074 kilometers), about 85% of the planet's radius. There is^100
evidence that it is partly molten or liquid. Mercury's outer shell,^100
comparable to Earth's outer shell(called the mantle and crust),^100
is only about 400 kilometers (250 miles) thick.

VENUS.name: venus
VENUS.first:
the second planet from the Sun, and the sixth^100
largest planet. It’s the hottest planet^100
in our solar system.
VENUS.introduction:
the second planet from the Sun, and Earth's^100
closest planetary neighbor. Venus is the third brightest object^100
in the sky after the Sun and Moon. Venus spins slowly in^100
the opposite direction from most planets.
VENUS.namesake:
named for the ancient Roman goddess of love and beauty,^100
who was known as Aphrodite to the ancient Greeks. Most features^100
on Venus are named for women. It’s the only planet^100
named after a female god.
VENUS.potential:
Thirty miles up (about 50 kilometers) from the^100
surface of Venus temperatures range from 86 to 158 Fahrenheit^100
(30 to 70 Celsius). This temperature range could accommodate Earthly life,^100
such as “extremophile” microbes. And atmospheric pressure at that^100
height is similar to what we find on Earth’s surface.^100

At the tops of Venus’ clouds,^100
whipped around the planet by winds measured as high as 224 mph (360 kph),^100
we find another transformation. Persistent, dark streaks appear. Scientists^100
are so far unable to explain why these streaks remain stubbornly intact,^100
even amid hurricane-force winds. They also have the odd habit^100
of absorbing ultraviolet radiation
VENUS.structure:
If we could slice Venus and Earth in half, pole to pole,^100
and place them side by side, they would look remarkably^100
similar. Each planet has an iron core enveloped by a hot-rock mantle;^100
the thinnest of skins forms a rocky, exterior crust. On both planets,^100
this thin skin changes form and sometimes erupts into volcanoes^100
in response to the ebb and flow of heat and^100
pressure deep beneath.

EARTH.name: earth
EARTH.first: our home planet – is the third planet from the Sun, and the fifth largest planet. It's the only place we know of inhabited by living things.
EARTH.introduction: While Earth is only the fifth largest planet in the solar system, it is the only world in our solar system with liquid water on the surface. Just slightly larger than nearby Venus, Earth is the biggest of the four planets closest to the Sun, all of which are made of rock and metal.
EARTH.namesake: Earth is the only planet in the solar system whose English name does not come from Greek or Roman mythology. The name was taken from Old English and Germanic. It simply means 'the ground.' There are, of course, many names for our planet in the thousands of languages spoken by the people of the third planet from the Sun.
EARTH.potential: Earth has a very hospitable temperature and mix of chemicals that have made life abundant here. Most notably, Earth is unique in that most of our planet is covered in liquid water, since the temperature allows liquid water to exist for extended periods of time. Earth's vast oceans provided a convenient place for life to begin about 3.8 billion years ago.
EARTH.structure: Earth is composed of four main layers, starting with an inner core at the planet's center, enveloped by the outer core, mantle, and crust.

MARS.name: mars
MARS.first:
the fourth planet from the Sun, and the seventh largest.^100
It’s the only planet we know of inhabited entirely by robots.
MARS.introduction:
Mars is one of the most explored bodies in our solar system,^100
and it's the only planet where we've sent rovers to^100
roam the alien landscape. NASA missions have found^100
lots of evidencethat Mars was much wetter and warmer,^100
with a thicker atmosphere,billions of years ago.
MARS.namesake:
Mars was named by the ancient Romans for their god of war^100
because its reddish color was reminiscent of blood.^100
Other civilizations also named the planet for this attribute^100
– for example, the Egyptians called it Her Desher, meaning^100
the red one.Even today, it is frequently called the Red Planet^100
because iron minerals in the Martian dirt oxidize, or rust,^100
causing the surface to look red.
MARS.potential:
Scientists don't expect to find living things currently^100
thriving on Mars. Instead, they're looking for signs of life^100
that existed long ago, when Mars was warmer and covered^100
with water.
MARS.structure:
Mars has a dense core at its center between^100
930 and 1,300 miles (1,500 to 2,100 kilometers) in radius.^100
It's made of iron, nickel, and sulfur. Surrounding the core^100
is a rockymantle between 770 and 1,170 miles^100
 (1,240 to 1,880 kilometers)thick, andabove that, a crust^100
made of iron, magnesium, aluminum, calcium,and^100
potassium.This crust is between 6 and 30 miles^100
(10 to 50 kilometers) deep.

JUPITER.name: jupiter
JUPITER.first:
the fifth planet from the Sun, and the largest in the solar^100
system more than twice as massive as the other planets^100
combined.
JUPITER.introduction:
Jupiter's signature stripes and swirls are actually cold,^100
windy clouds of ammonia and water, floating in an^100
atmosphere of hydrogen and helium. The dark orange^100
stripes are called belts, while the bands are called^100
zones, and they flow east and west in opposite directions.^100
Jupiter’s iconic Great Red Spot is a giant storm bigger^100
than Earth that has for hundreds of years.
JUPITER.namesake:
Jupiter, being the biggest, gets its name from the king^100
of the ancient Roman gods
JUPITER.potential:
Jupiter’s environment is probably not conducive to life^100
as we know it. The temperatures, pressures, and^100
materials that characterize this planet are most likely^100
 too extreme and volatilefor organisms to adapt to. While^100
 planet Jupiter is an unlikely place forliving things to^100
 take hold, the same is not true of some of its many moons.^100

Europa is one of the likeliest places to find life elsewhere^100
in our solar system.There is evidence of a vast ocean^100
just beneath its icy crust, wherelife could possibly^100
be supported.
JUPITER.structure:
The composition of Jupiter is similar to that of the Sun^100
– mostly hydrogen and helium. Deep in the atmosphere,^100
pressure and temperature increase, compressing^100
the hydrogen gas into a liquid.gives Jupiter the largest ocean^100
in the solar system –an ocean made ofinstead of water.^100

Scientists think that, at depths  perhaps halfway to planet's^100
center, the pressure becomes so great that electrons^100
are squeezed the hydrogen atoms, making the liquid electrically^100
conducting like metal.Jupiter's fast rotation is thought to drive^100
electrical currents in this region, the spinning of the liquid^100
metallic hydrogen acting like a dynamo, generatingplanet's^100
owerful magnetic field.^100

Deeper down, Jupiter's central core had longamystery. ^100
Scientiststheorized Jupiter was a mostly homogeneous^100
 mix ofhydrogen and helium gases, surrounding^100
a small,solid core ofheavierelements^100
– rock, and metal formed from debris and small^100
objects swirling aroundthat area of the ^100
embryonicsolar system 4 billion years ago.

SATURN.name: saturn
SATURN.first:
the sixth planet from the Sun, and the second largest in the^100
solar system. It’s surrounded by beautiful rings.
SATURN.introduction:
Like fellow gas giant Jupiter, Saturn is a massive ball^100
made mostly of hydrogen and helium. Saturn is not the only^100
planet to have rings, but none are as spectacular or as complex^100
as Saturn's. Saturn also has dozens of moons. From the jets of ^100
water thatspray from Saturn's moon Enceladus to the^100
methane lakes on smoggy Titan,the Saturn system is a rich^100
source of scientific discovery and still holds many mysteries.
SATURN.namesake:
The farthest planet from Earth discovered by the unaided^100
human eye, Saturn has been known since ancient times. The planet is named^100
for the Roman god of agriculture and wealth, who was^100
also the father of Jupiter.
SATURN.potential:
Saturn's environment is^100
not conducive to life as we know it. The temperatures, pressures, and materials^100
that characterize this planet are most likely too extreme and volatile for^100
organisms to adapt to.
SATURN.structure:
Like Jupiter, Saturnis made mostly of hydrogen and helium.^100
At Saturn's center is a dense core of metals like iron^100
and nickel surrounded by rocky material and other compounds^100
solidified by intense pressure and heat. It is enveloped by liquid^100
metallic hydrogen inside a layer of liquid hydrogen –similar to ^100
Jupiter's core but considerably smaller.^100

It's hard to imagine, but Saturn is the only planet in our solar^100
system with an average density that is less than water. ^100
The giant gas planet could float in a bathtub if such a colossal^100
thing existed.

URANUS.name: uranus
URANUS.first:
the seventh planet from the Sun, and the third largest planet^100
in our solar system. It appears to spin sideways.
URANUS.introduction:
Uranus is a very cold and windy world. The ice giant is surrounded^100
by 13 faint rings and 28 small moons. Uranus rotates at a nearly ^100
90-degree angle from the plane of its orbit. This unique tilt makes^100
Uranus appear to spin sideways, orbiting the Sun like a rolling ball.^100
Uranus was the first planet found with the aid of a telescope.^100

It was discovered in 1781 by astronomer William Herschel, although^100
he originally thought it was either a comet or a star. It was two^100
years later that the object was universally accepted as a new^100
planet, in part because of observations by astronomer Johann^100
Elert Bode.
URANUS.namesake:
William Herschel tried unsuccessfully to name his discovery^100
Georgium Sidus after King George III. Instead, the planet was^100
named for Uranus, the Greek god of the sky, as suggested^100
by Johann Bode.
URANUS.potential:
Uranus' environment is not conducive to life as we know it.^100
The temperatures, pressures, and materials that characterize^100
this planet are most likely too extreme and volatile for^100
organisms to adapt to.
URANUS.structure:
Uranus is one of two ice giants in the outer solar system^100
(the other is Neptune). Most (80% or more) of the planet's^100
mass is made up of a hot dense fluid of icy materials – water,^100
methane, and ammonia – above a small rocky core. Near the core,^100
 it heats up to 9,000 degreesFahrenheit (4,982 degrees Celsius).^100

Uranus is slightly larger in diameter than its neighbor Neptune,^100
yet smaller in mass. It is the second least dense planet; Saturn is^100
the least dense of all. Uranus gets its blue-green color from^100
methane  gas in the atmosphere. Sunlight passes through the^100
atmosphere and is reflected back out by Uranus' cloud tops.^100
Methane gas absorbs the red portion of the light, resulting in a blue-green color.

NEPTUNE.name: neptune
NEPTUNE.first:
the eighth, and most distant planet from the Sun.^100
It’s the fourth-largest, and the first planet discovered^100
with math.
NEPTUNE.introduction:
Dark, cold, and whipped by supersonic winds,^100
ice giant Neptune is more than 30 times as far from the Sun as^100
 Earth. Neptune is the only planet in our solar system not visible to the^100
naked eye. In 2011 Neptune completed its first 165-year orbit since its ^100
discovery in 1846.Neptune is so far from the Sun that high noon on the big blue planet^100
would seem like dim twilight to us. The warm light we see here on our home ^100
planet is roughly 900 times as bright as sunlight on Neptune.
NEPTUNE.namesake:
The ice giant Neptune was the first planet located^100
through mathematical calculations. Using predictions made by Urbain^100
Le Verrier, Johann Galle discovered the planet in 1846. The planet is named^100
after the Roman god of the sea, as suggested by Le Verrier.
NEPTUNE.potential:
Neptune's environment is not conducive to life as we know it.^100
The temperatures, pressures, and materials that characterize^100
this planet are most likely too extreme, and volatile for organisms^100
to adapt to.
NEPTUNE.structure:
Neptune is one of two ice giants in the outer solar system^100
(the other is Uranus). Most (80% or more) of the planet's mass^100
is made up of a hot dense fluid of icy materials – water, methane, and^100
ammonia – above a small, rocky core. Of the giant planets, Neptune is the densest.^100
Scientists think there might be an ocean of super hot water under Neptune's cold^100
clouds. It does not boil away because incredibly high pressure^100
keeps it locked inside.
